_link.title: I can identify which half-reactions will occur in a galvanic cell from given species

toLevel2.question: In a galvanic cell with multiple species present, which species undergoes reduction at the cathode?
toLevel2.correct: The species highest on the left of the electrochemical series
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strongest oxidising agent (highest on the left) has the greatest tendency to gain electrons, so it is reduced at the cathode.

distractors.answer: The species lowest on the left of the electrochemical series
distractors.explanation: The lowest on the left is the weakest oxidising agent and does not preferentially undergo reduction.

distractors.answer: The species highest on the right of the electrochemical series
distractors.explanation: Species on the right are the reduced forms. The oxidised form (left side) is what gets reduced at the cathode.

distractors.answer: The species lowest on the right of the electrochemical series
distractors.explanation: The lowest on the right is the strongest reducing agent, which undergoes oxidation at the anode, not reduction.

toLevel2.question: In a galvanic cell with multiple species present, which species undergoes oxidation at the anode?
toLevel2.correct: The species lowest on the right of the electrochemical series
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strongest reducing agent (lowest on the right) has the greatest tendency to lose electrons, so it is oxidised at the anode.

distractors.answer: The species highest on the right of the electrochemical series
distractors.explanation: The highest on the right is the weakest reducing agent and does not preferentially undergo oxidation.

distractors.answer: The species lowest on the left of the electrochemical series
distractors.explanation: Species on the left are the oxidised forms. The reduced form (right side) is what gets oxidised at the anode.

distractors.answer: The species highest on the left of the electrochemical series
distractors.explanation: The highest on the left is the strongest oxidising agent, which undergoes reduction at the cathode.

toLevel2.question: What happens to species present in a galvanic cell that are neither the strongest oxidising agent nor the strongest reducing agent?
toLevel2.correct: They act as spectator ions and do not participate in the cell reaction
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Only the strongest oxidising agent (reduced) and strongest reducing agent (oxidised) react. Other species remain unchanged as spectators.

distractors.answer: They undergo both oxidation and reduction simultaneously in the cell
distractors.explanation: Spectator species do not undergo any redox reaction. Only the most reactive species participate.

distractors.answer: They react at both electrodes to produce a higher cell voltage
distractors.explanation: Only one reduction and one oxidation reaction occur. Intermediate species are spectators.

distractors.answer: They decompose into simpler ions due to the electrical energy produced
distractors.explanation: Galvanic cells do not decompose spectator species. They remain unchanged in solution.

toLevel2.question: A solution contains Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V), Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V), and Ni²⁺ (E° = −0.25 V) with an Fe electrode (E° = −0.44 V). Which species is reduced at the cathode?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ has the highest E° value (+0.34 V), making it the strongest oxidising agent. It is reduced at the cathode.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺
distractors.explanation: Ni²⁺ (−0.25 V) is a weaker oxidising agent than Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) and acts as a spectator.

distractors.answer: Zn²⁺
distractors.explanation: Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V) is the weakest oxidising agent present and acts as a spectator.

distractors.answer: Fe²⁺
distractors.explanation: Fe is present as a solid electrode (reducing agent), not as Fe²⁺ ions being reduced.

toLevel2.question: In the same cell (Cu²⁺, Zn²⁺, Ni²⁺ in solution with Fe electrode), which species is oxidised at the anode?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Fe(s) has E° = −0.44 V, making it the strongest reducing agent present (lowest on the right). It is oxidised at the anode.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ is already in its oxidised form and is actually reduced at the cathode, not oxidised.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺
distractors.explanation: Ni²⁺ is already oxidised (it is a cation in solution) and acts as a spectator ion.

distractors.answer: Zn²⁺
distractors.explanation: Zn²⁺ is already in its oxidised form and acts as a spectator ion in this cell.

toLevel2.question: In a galvanic cell with multiple species, the strongest oxidising agent is always reduced at the cathode.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strongest oxidising agent (highest E° on the left of the ECS) has the greatest tendency to gain electrons, so it undergoes reduction at the cathode.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may confuse oxidising agents with reducing agents. The strongest oxidising agent is indeed reduced at the cathode.

toLevel2.question: All metal ions present in a galvanic cell solution are reduced at the cathode during the cell reaction.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Only the strongest oxidising agent (highest E°) is reduced. Other metal ions act as spectator ions and remain unchanged.

distractors.answer: True
distractors.explanation: Students may think all cations are reduced, but only the one with the highest E° value undergoes reduction.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about identifying half-reactions in galvanic cells.
toLevel2.sentence: The species {{blank:1}} on the left of the ECS undergoes reduction, while the species {{blank:2}} on the right undergoes oxidation.

1.correctExplanation: The highest species on the left of the ECS is the strongest oxidising agent and undergoes reduction.

distractors.answer: lowest
distractors.explanation: The lowest on the left is the weakest oxidising agent. The highest is reduced.

distractors.answer: middle
distractors.explanation: Middle species are typically spectators. The highest on the left is reduced.

2.correctExplanation: The lowest species on the right of the ECS is the strongest reducing agent and undergoes oxidation.

distractors.answer: highest
distractors.explanation: The highest on the right is the weakest reducing agent. The lowest is oxidised.

distractors.answer: middle
distractors.explanation: Middle species are typically spectators. The lowest on the right is oxidised.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about spectator species in galvanic cells.
toLevel2.sentence: Species that are neither the strongest oxidising agent nor the strongest reducing agent act as {{blank:1}} ions.

1.correctExplanation: These species do not participate in the electrode reactions and remain unchanged in solution.

distractors.answer: reactive
distractors.explanation: These species are not reactive in the cell. Only the strongest agents react.

distractors.answer: catalytic
distractors.explanation: Spectator ions do not act as catalysts. They simply remain unchanged.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the statement about the galvanic cell example.
toLevel2.sentence: With Cu²⁺, Zn²⁺, and Ni²⁺ ions and an Fe electrode, {{blank:1}} is reduced at the cathode and {{blank:2}} is oxidised at the anode.

1.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ has the highest E° (+0.34 V) of the oxidising agents present, so it is reduced.

distractors.answer: Zn²⁺
distractors.explanation: Zn²⁺ has E° = −0.76 V, much lower than Cu²⁺. It is a spectator.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺
distractors.explanation: Ni²⁺ has E° = −0.25 V, lower than Cu²⁺. It is a spectator.

2.correctExplanation: Fe(s) is the strongest reducing agent present (lowest on the right, E° = −0.44 V), so it is oxidised.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ is an oxidising agent that is reduced, not oxidised.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺
distractors.explanation: Ni²⁺ is already oxidised and acts as a spectator ion.

toLevel3.question: A solution contains Ag⁺ (E° = +0.80 V), Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V), and Pb²⁺ (E° = −0.13 V) ions with a Zn electrode (E° = −0.76 V). Which pair of half-reactions occurs in the galvanic cell?
toLevel3.correct: Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag(s) at the cathode and Zn(s) → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ at the anode
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ has the highest E° (+0.80 V) so it is reduced. Zn(s) is the only reducing agent and is lowest on the right, so it is oxidised.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu(s) at the cathode and Zn(s) → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ at the anode
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) is a weaker oxidising agent than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V). Ag⁺ is preferentially reduced.

distractors.answer: Pb²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Pb(s) at the cathode and Zn(s) → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ at the anode
distractors.explanation: Pb²⁺ (−0.13 V) is the weakest oxidising agent. Ag⁺ (+0.80 V) is reduced instead.

distractors.answer: Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag(s) at the cathode and Pb²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Pb(s) at the anode
distractors.explanation: Pb²⁺ is an oxidising agent (left side of ECS) and cannot be oxidised further. Zn(s) is oxidised.

toLevel3.question: In a cell containing Fe²⁺ (E° = −0.44 V), Ni²⁺ (E° = −0.25 V), and Sn²⁺ (E° = −0.14 V) with a Mg electrode (E° = −2.37 V), which species are spectator ions?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Sn²⁺ has the highest E° (−0.14 V) so it is reduced. Mg(s) is the strongest reducing agent and is oxidised. Fe²⁺ and Ni²⁺ are spectators.

distractors.answer: Sn²⁺ and Ni²⁺
distractors.explanation: Sn²⁺ has the highest E° and is reduced at the cathode. It is not a spectator.

distractors.answer: Fe²⁺ and Sn²⁺
distractors.explanation: Sn²⁺ is reduced at the cathode (highest E°). Only Fe²⁺ and Ni²⁺ are spectators.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺ and Mg²⁺
distractors.explanation: Mg²⁺ forms as a product of the anode reaction. Ni²⁺ is a spectator, but Mg²⁺ is not initially present.

toLevel3.question: Why does Cu²⁺ get reduced preferentially over Zn²⁺ when both are present in a galvanic cell solution?
toLevel3.correct: Cu²⁺ has a higher E° value (+0.34 V vs −0.76 V), making it a stronger oxidising agent
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The species with the higher E° is a stronger oxidising agent and has a greater tendency to gain electrons, so it is reduced first.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ has a larger ionic radius than Zn²⁺, attracting more electrons
distractors.explanation: Ionic radius does not determine which species is reduced. E° values determine the strongest oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ is more concentrated than Zn²⁺ in the galvanic cell solution
distractors.explanation: Under standard conditions, concentrations are equal (1 mol/L). E° values, not concentration, determine priority.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ has a higher atomic number than Zn²⁺ in the periodic table
distractors.explanation: Atomic number does not determine reduction priority. E° values from the ECS determine which species is reduced.

toLevel3.question: A galvanic cell contains Br₂/Br⁻ (E° = +1.09 V) and I₂/I⁻ (E° = +0.54 V) half-cells connected with a Zn/Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V) half-cell. Which half-reaction occurs at the cathode?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Br₂ has the highest E° (+1.09 V) of the oxidising agents, so it is the strongest oxidising agent and is reduced at the cathode.

distractors.answer: I₂ + 2e⁻ → 2I⁻
distractors.explanation: I₂ (+0.54 V) is a weaker oxidising agent than Br₂ (+1.09 V). Br₂ is reduced preferentially.

distractors.answer: Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Zn(s)
distractors.explanation: Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V) is the weakest oxidising agent. Br₂ is reduced, and Zn is oxidised at the anode.

distractors.answer: 2Br⁻ → Br₂ + 2e⁻
distractors.explanation: Br₂ is the strongest oxidising agent, so it is reduced (gains electrons), not oxidised.

toLevel3.question: A student has a cell with Fe²⁺, Cu²⁺, and Ag⁺ ions. They predict Cu²⁺ is reduced at the cathode. What is wrong with this prediction?
toLevel3.correct: Ag⁺ has a higher E° (+0.80 V) than Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) and should be reduced instead
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ is the strongest oxidising agent present (highest E°), so it is reduced preferentially at the cathode, not Cu²⁺.

distractors.answer: Fe²⁺ should be reduced because it has the lowest E° value of the three
distractors.explanation: The lowest E° means weakest oxidising agent. The strongest (highest E°, Ag⁺) is reduced.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺ cannot be reduced because copper is already a stable element
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ can be reduced to Cu(s). The issue is that Ag⁺ is a stronger oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: All three ions are reduced simultaneously at the cathode in practice
distractors.explanation: Only the strongest oxidising agent (Ag⁺) undergoes reduction. The others are spectators.

toLevel3.question: In a galvanic cell, why can't a species that is already in its oxidised form (such as Zn²⁺ in solution) be oxidised further?
toLevel3.correct: It has already lost its electrons and has no further electrons to lose under standard conditions
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Zn²⁺ is already the oxidised form of zinc. To be oxidised, a species must be in its reduced form (right side of ECS) with electrons to lose.

distractors.answer: It can be oxidised further but only at very high temperatures in the cell
distractors.explanation: Under the conditions studied, Zn²⁺ cannot be oxidised further. It is already in its stable oxidised form.

distractors.answer: It can be oxidised if a stronger oxidising agent is added to the solution
distractors.explanation: A stronger oxidising agent would oxidise the strongest reducing agent, not an already-oxidised species like Zn²⁺.

distractors.answer: Oxidised forms are always found at the anode, so they cannot react further
distractors.explanation: Location does not determine reactivity. The issue is that Zn²⁺ has no electrons to lose.

toLevel3.question: When multiple reducing agents are present, the one with the lowest E° value (furthest down the right side of the ECS) is oxidised at the anode.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The lowest E° on the right side indicates the strongest reducing agent, which has the greatest tendency to lose electrons and is oxidised at the anode.

distractors.answer: False
distractors.explanation: Students may think the highest E° reducing agent reacts, but the lowest E° indicates the strongest reducing agent.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the statement about selecting half-reactions in a galvanic cell.
toLevel3.sentence: When multiple oxidising agents are present, the one with the {{blank:1}} E° value is reduced because it is the {{blank:2}} oxidising agent.

1.correctExplanation: The highest E° indicates the greatest tendency to gain electrons, making it the strongest oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: lowest
distractors.explanation: The lowest E° is the weakest oxidising agent. The highest E° is reduced preferentially.

distractors.answer: most negative
distractors.explanation: The most negative E° is the weakest oxidising agent. The highest (most positive) is reduced.

2.correctExplanation: Higher E° means stronger tendency to gain electrons, making it the strongest oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: weakest
distractors.explanation: The species with the highest E° is the strongest, not the weakest, oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: most stable
distractors.explanation: Stability does not determine which oxidising agent reacts. Strength (highest E°) determines priority.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the statement about the role of unreacted species.
toLevel3.sentence: In a cell with Ag⁺, Cu²⁺, and Pb²⁺ ions, if Ag⁺ is reduced at the cathode, then Cu²⁺ and Pb²⁺ act as {{blank:1}} because they are {{blank:2}} oxidising agents than Ag⁺.

1.correctExplanation: These ions do not participate in the electrode reactions and remain unchanged in solution.

distractors.answer: reducing agents
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ and Pb²⁺ are oxidising agents (oxidised forms), not reducing agents.

distractors.answer: catalysts
distractors.explanation: Spectator ions are not catalysts. They simply do not react in this cell.

2.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) and Pb²⁺ (−0.13 V) have lower E° values than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V), making them weaker oxidising agents.

distractors.answer: stronger
distractors.explanation: If they were stronger, they would be reduced instead of Ag⁺. They are weaker.

distractors.answer: equally strong
distractors.explanation: They have different E° values (lower than Ag⁺), so they are weaker, not equal.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the identification of reactions in the example cell.
toLevel3.sentence: With Cu²⁺, Zn²⁺, Ni²⁺ in solution and an Fe electrode, the cell voltage is E°(cathode) − E°(anode) = {{blank:1}} − ({{blank:2}}) = +0.78 V.

1.correctExplanation: Cu²⁺/Cu has E° = +0.34 V and is the cathode reaction (strongest oxidising agent).

distractors.explanation: −0.25 V is the E° for Ni²⁺/Ni, which is a spectator, not the cathode reaction.
−0.76 V is the E° for Zn²⁺/Zn, which is a spectator, not the cathode reaction.

2.correctExplanation: Fe²⁺/Fe has E° = −0.44 V and is the anode reaction (Fe is the strongest reducing agent present).

distractors.explanation: +0.34 V is Cu²⁺/Cu, the cathode reaction, not the anode.
−0.25 V is Ni²⁺/Ni, a spectator ion, not the anode reaction.

toLevel4.question: A solution contains Fe³⁺ (E° = +0.77 V), Cu²⁺ (E° = +0.34 V), Sn²⁺ (E° = −0.14 V), and Zn²⁺ (E° = −0.76 V) with a Mg electrode (E° = −2.37 V). Calculate the cell potential.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Fe³⁺ is reduced (highest E° = +0.77 V). Mg is oxidised (lowest E° = −2.37 V). E°cell = +0.77 − (−2.37) = +3.14 V.

distractors.explanation: This uses Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) at the cathode instead of Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V). Fe³⁺ is the strongest oxidising agent.
This uses Fe³⁺ − Sn²⁺ = 0.77 − (−0.14) = 0.91 V or similar. The anode must be Mg (−2.37 V).
This may use Sn²⁺ or Zn²⁺ at the anode. Mg(s) is the strongest reducing agent (E° = −2.37 V).

toLevel4.question: A cell has Ag⁺, Fe³⁺, Cu²⁺ ions in solution with electrodes of Zn and Pb. Identify the cathode reaction and the anode reaction.
toLevel4.correct: Cathode: Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag (E° = +0.80 V); Anode: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻ (E° = −0.76 V)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ has the highest E° (+0.80 V) of the oxidising agents. Zn has the lowest E° (−0.76 V) of the reducing agents (Zn vs Pb at −0.13 V).

distractors.answer: Cathode: Fe³⁺ + e⁻ → Fe²⁺; Anode: Zn → Zn²⁺ + 2e⁻
distractors.explanation: Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) is a weaker oxidising agent than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V). Ag⁺ is reduced.

distractors.answer: Cathode: Ag⁺ + e⁻ → Ag; Anode: Pb → Pb²⁺ + 2e⁻
distractors.explanation: Pb (−0.13 V) is a weaker reducing agent than Zn (−0.76 V). Zn is oxidised.

distractors.answer: Cathode: Cu²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Cu; Anode: Pb → Pb²⁺ + 2e⁻
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) is weaker than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V), and Pb (−0.13 V) is weaker than Zn (−0.76 V).

toLevel4.question: A cell contains I₂/I⁻ (E° = +0.54 V), Sn⁴⁺/Sn²⁺ (E° = +0.15 V), and Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = −0.44 V). Which species are the spectators?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: I₂ is the strongest oxidising agent (E° = +0.54 V, reduced). Fe(s) is the strongest reducing agent (E° = −0.44 V, oxidised). The Sn⁴⁺/Sn²⁺ couple is intermediate and spectates.

distractors.answer: I₂ and I⁻ are spectators
distractors.explanation: I₂ has the highest E° and is reduced at the cathode. It is not a spectator.

distractors.answer: Fe²⁺ and Fe are spectators
distractors.explanation: Fe(s) is the strongest reducing agent and is oxidised at the anode. It is not a spectator.

distractors.answer: I⁻ and Fe²⁺ are spectators
distractors.explanation: I⁻ and Fe²⁺ are products of the electrode reactions, not spectators. The Sn couple is the spectator.

toLevel4.question: A student has access to Al(s), Cu(s), Ag(s), and a solution of Fe³⁺. Which metal should be used as the anode to maximise the cell voltage?
toLevel4.correct: Al(s), because it has the lowest E° (−1.66 V) and is the strongest reducing agent
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) is reduced at the cathode. Al (−1.66 V) gives the largest E°cell = +0.77 − (−1.66) = +2.43 V.

distractors.answer: Ag(s), because it has the highest E° (+0.80 V) and gives the largest difference
distractors.explanation: Ag (+0.80 V) is a weaker reducing agent than Fe²⁺/Fe. Ag⁺/Ag actually has higher E° than Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺, making it unsuitable.

distractors.answer: Cu(s), because it is commonly used in galvanic cells as an electrode
distractors.explanation: Common use does not determine maximum voltage. Al (−1.66 V) gives a larger potential difference.

distractors.answer: Any metal works equally well because E°cell depends only on the cathode
distractors.explanation: E°cell depends on both cathode and anode. The anode metal's E° directly affects the cell voltage.

toLevel4.question: A galvanic cell uses Cl₂/Cl⁻ (E° = +1.36 V) and Br₂/Br⁻ (E° = +1.09 V) half-cells with a Ni electrode (E° = −0.25 V). Which reaction occurs at the cathode and what is E°cell?
toLevel4.correct: Cl₂ + 2e⁻ → 2Cl⁻ at the cathode; E°cell = +1.36 − (−0.25) = +1.61 V
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Cl₂ has the highest E° (+1.36 V) so it is reduced. Ni is the strongest reducing agent (−0.25 V) and is oxidised.

distractors.answer: Br₂ + 2e⁻ → 2Br⁻ at the cathode; E°cell = +1.09 − (−0.25) = +1.34 V
distractors.explanation: Br₂ (+1.09 V) is a weaker oxidising agent than Cl₂ (+1.36 V). Cl₂ is reduced instead.

distractors.answer: Cl₂ + 2e⁻ → 2Cl⁻ at the cathode; E°cell = +1.36 − (+1.09) = +0.27 V
distractors.explanation: This incorrectly uses Br₂ as the anode. Br₂ is an oxidising agent, not a reducing agent. Ni is oxidised.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺ + 2e⁻ → Ni at the cathode; E°cell = −0.25 − (−1.36) = +1.11 V
distractors.explanation: Ni is the reducing agent (oxidised at anode). Cl₂ has the highest E° and is reduced.

toLevel4.question: In a mixture containing Mn²⁺(aq), Al³⁺(aq), Zn²⁺(aq) and Fe(s), identify which species reacts at each electrode.
toLevel4.correct: Zn²⁺ is reduced at cathode (E° = −0.76 V is highest); Fe is oxidised at anode (E° = −0.44 V)
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Among the oxidising agents: Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V) > Mn²⁺ (−1.18 V) > Al³⁺ (−1.66 V). Zn²⁺ has the highest E° so it is reduced. Fe(s) is the only reducing agent present.

distractors.answer: Al³⁺ is reduced at cathode; Fe is oxidised at anode
distractors.explanation: Al³⁺ (−1.66 V) has the lowest E° of the three cations. Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V) has the highest and is reduced.

distractors.answer: Mn²⁺ is reduced at cathode; Fe is oxidised at anode
distractors.explanation: Mn²⁺ (−1.18 V) has a lower E° than Zn²⁺ (−0.76 V). Zn²⁺ is the strongest oxidising agent here.

distractors.answer: Fe²⁺ is reduced at cathode; Al is oxidised at anode
distractors.explanation: Fe²⁺ is not initially present, and Al(s) is not present either. Only Fe(s) is a reducing agent here.

toLevel4.question: A cell has Co²⁺ (E° = −0.28 V), Cd²⁺ (E° = −0.40 V), and Pb²⁺ (E° = −0.13 V) ions in solution with an Al electrode (E° = −1.66 V). What is the cell potential?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Pb²⁺ has the highest E° (−0.13 V) so is reduced. Al is oxidised (−1.66 V). E°cell = −0.13 − (−1.66) = +1.53 V.

distractors.explanation: This uses Co²⁺ (−0.28 V) at the cathode: −0.28 − (−1.66) = +1.38 V. But Pb²⁺ (−0.13 V) has higher E°.
This uses Cd²⁺ (−0.40 V) at the cathode: −0.40 − (−1.66) = +1.26 V. But Pb²⁺ (−0.13 V) has higher E°.
This calculates Pb²⁺ − Co²⁺ = −0.13 − (−0.28) = +0.15 V, using the wrong anode. Al is oxidised.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the analysis of half-reaction selection.
toLevel4.sentence: In a cell with Fe³⁺, Cu²⁺, and Sn²⁺ in solution with a Zn electrode, {{blank:1}} is reduced (E° = {{blank:2}} V) because it is the strongest oxidising agent present.

1.correctExplanation: Fe³⁺ has E° = +0.77 V, the highest of the three cations, making it the strongest oxidising agent.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) has a lower E° than Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) and is a spectator.

distractors.answer: Sn²⁺
distractors.explanation: Sn²⁺ (−0.14 V) has a much lower E° than Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) and is a spectator.

2.correctExplanation: The E° for Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ is +0.77 V, the highest of the available oxidising agents.

distractors.explanation: +0.34 V is the E° for Cu²⁺/Cu, not Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺.
−0.14 V is the E° for Sn²⁺/Sn, not Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the cell voltage calculation for the given system.
toLevel4.sentence: With Ag⁺, Cu²⁺, Ni²⁺ in solution and an Al electrode, E°cell = E°({{blank:1}}) − E°({{blank:2}}) = +0.80 − (−1.66) = +2.46 V.

1.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ has the highest E° (+0.80 V) of the oxidising agents, so it is the cathode reaction.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺/Cu
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) is weaker than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V). Ag⁺ is reduced at the cathode.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺/Ni
distractors.explanation: Ni²⁺ (−0.25 V) is much weaker than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V). Ag⁺ is reduced.

2.correctExplanation: Al has E° = −1.66 V and is the strongest reducing agent (only metal electrode), so it is the anode reaction.

distractors.answer: Ni²⁺/Ni
distractors.explanation: Ni is in solution as Ni²⁺, not as a metal electrode. Al is the reducing agent.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺/Cu
distractors.explanation: Cu is in solution as Cu²⁺, not as a metal electrode. Al is the reducing agent.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the statement about predicting reactions in complex mixtures.
toLevel4.sentence: To maximise cell voltage, choose the oxidising agent with the {{blank:1}} E° for the cathode and the reducing agent with the {{blank:2}} E° for the anode.

1.correctExplanation: The highest E° oxidising agent has the greatest tendency to be reduced, maximising the cathode potential.

distractors.answer: lowest
distractors.explanation: The lowest E° gives the weakest oxidising agent, minimising cell voltage.

distractors.answer: most negative
distractors.explanation: Most negative E° means weakest oxidising agent. The highest (most positive) maximises voltage.

2.correctExplanation: The lowest E° reducing agent has the greatest tendency to be oxidised, maximising the anode contribution to cell voltage.

distractors.answer: highest
distractors.explanation: The highest E° reducing agent is the weakest and minimises the cell voltage.

distractors.answer: most positive
distractors.explanation: Most positive E° means weakest reducing agent. The lowest maximises voltage.

toLevel5.question: A galvanic cell contains Ag⁺, Cu²⁺, Fe³⁺, and Pb²⁺ ions in solution with electrodes of Zn and Al. Evaluate: Will the cell voltage equal E°(Ag⁺/Ag) − E°(Al³⁺/Al)?
toLevel5.correct: Yes, because Ag⁺ is the strongest oxidising agent (+0.80 V) and Al is the strongest reducing agent (−1.66 V)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ has the highest E° of the cations. Al has the lowest E° of the metals. E°cell = +0.80 − (−1.66) = +2.46 V.

distractors.answer: No, because Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) is closer in E° to Ag⁺ and will be reduced instead
distractors.explanation: Closeness in E° is irrelevant. Only the highest E° (Ag⁺ at +0.80 V) determines the cathode reaction.

distractors.answer: No, because both Ag⁺ and Fe³⁺ are reduced simultaneously at the cathode
distractors.explanation: Only one reduction reaction occurs in a galvanic cell — the one with the highest E°.

distractors.answer: No, the voltage equals the sum of all E° values of the species present
distractors.explanation: Cell voltage uses only the cathode and anode reactions, not a sum of all species.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that in a cell with Cl₂, Br₂, and I₂ as oxidising agents, all three halogens will be reduced because they are all strong oxidising agents. Evaluate this claim.
toLevel5.correct: Incorrect — only Cl₂ (highest E° = +1.36 V) is reduced; Br₂ and I₂ are spectators
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Regardless of how strong the other oxidising agents are, only the strongest one (highest E°) undergoes reduction in a galvanic cell.

distractors.answer: Correct — all three halogens have positive E° values, so all are reduced
distractors.explanation: Having a positive E° does not guarantee reduction. Only the strongest oxidising agent (highest E°) is reduced.

distractors.answer: Incorrect — I₂ is reduced first because it is the weakest and easiest to reduce
distractors.explanation: The weakest oxidising agent is the least likely to be reduced. The strongest (Cl₂) is reduced.

distractors.answer: Correct — the cell produces three different reduction products simultaneously
distractors.explanation: A galvanic cell has one cathode reaction. Only Cl₂ (highest E°) is reduced.

toLevel5.question: Consider a cell with Fe²⁺/Fe (E° = −0.44 V) and Sn⁴⁺/Sn²⁺ (E° = +0.15 V). If Ni²⁺ (E° = −0.25 V) is added to the solution, does the cell voltage change?
toLevel5.correct: No, because Ni²⁺ becomes a spectator — Sn⁴⁺ remains the strongest oxidising agent and Fe remains the strongest reducing agent
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Ni²⁺ (−0.25 V) is weaker than Sn⁴⁺ (+0.15 V) as an oxidising agent. The cathode and anode reactions are unchanged.

distractors.answer: Yes, because adding Ni²⁺ creates a new half-cell that contributes additional voltage
distractors.explanation: Spectator ions do not contribute to cell voltage. Only the reacting half-cells determine E°cell.

distractors.answer: Yes, because Ni²⁺ is reduced instead of Sn⁴⁺ since it requires fewer electrons
distractors.explanation: Electron count does not determine priority. Sn⁴⁺ has a higher E° and is still preferentially reduced.

distractors.answer: Yes, the voltage decreases because Ni²⁺ competes with Sn⁴⁺ for electrons
distractors.explanation: There is no competition — only the strongest oxidising agent reacts. Ni²⁺ is a spectator.

toLevel5.question: A cell has Cu²⁺(aq), Ag⁺(aq), and Fe²⁺(aq) with a Zn electrode. After the cell operates, the student observes silver metal deposited. They then claim Cu²⁺ will be reduced next after Ag⁺ is consumed. Is this valid?
toLevel5.correct: Yes — once Ag⁺ is depleted, Cu²⁺ becomes the strongest remaining oxidising agent and will be reduced
toLevel5.correctExplanation: After Ag⁺ is consumed, Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) has the highest E° of the remaining oxidising agents and takes over at the cathode.

distractors.answer: No — once Ag⁺ is consumed, the cell stops because only one cathode reaction is possible
distractors.explanation: A cell can continue with the next strongest oxidising agent after the first is depleted.

distractors.answer: No — Fe²⁺ will be reduced next because it is alphabetically next in the series
distractors.explanation: Alphabetical order is irrelevant. Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) has a higher E° than Fe²⁺ (−0.44 V) and is reduced next.

distractors.answer: Yes, but the cell voltage will increase because Cu is a better conductor
distractors.explanation: The voltage will actually decrease because Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) has a lower E° than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V).

toLevel5.question: Analyse: In a galvanic cell with Al and Mg electrodes in a solution of Cu²⁺ ions, a student says Mg is the anode because it is more reactive. Evaluate using the ECS.
toLevel5.correct: Incorrect — Al (E° = −1.66 V) is actually lower than Mg (E° = −2.37 V)... wait. Mg at −2.37 V IS lower. The student is correct.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Mg has E° = −2.37 V (lower than Al at −1.66 V), making Mg the stronger reducing agent. Mg is oxidised at the anode. The student is correct.

distractors.answer: Incorrect — Al is the anode because it has a more negative E° than Mg
distractors.explanation: Al (−1.66 V) is less negative than Mg (−2.37 V). Mg is the stronger reducing agent and the anode.

distractors.answer: Incorrect — both metals are oxidised equally at the anode in this cell
distractors.explanation: Only one metal acts as the anode. Mg (−2.37 V) is the stronger reducing agent and is preferentially oxidised.

distractors.answer: Incorrect — the anode is always the metal listed first alphabetically
distractors.explanation: Alphabetical order is irrelevant. The ECS determines that Mg (lower E°) is the anode.

toLevel5.question: A student designs a cell with Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (E° = +0.77 V) at one electrode and Cu²⁺/Cu (E° = +0.34 V) at the other. They place Fe(s) as an electrode. Analyse the problem.
toLevel5.correct: Fe(s) could be oxidised to Fe²⁺ (E° = −0.44 V), which is a different half-cell from Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (+0.77 V)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Iron has two redox couples: Fe²⁺/Fe (−0.44 V) and Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (+0.77 V). Using Fe(s) introduces the −0.44 V couple, not the +0.77 V couple, which changes the cell design.

distractors.answer: There is no problem — Fe(s) directly participates in the Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ half-cell
distractors.explanation: Fe(s) participates in Fe²⁺/Fe (−0.44 V), not Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (+0.77 V). An inert electrode is needed for Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺.

distractors.answer: The problem is that Fe is not conductive enough for use as an electrode
distractors.explanation: Iron is a good conductor. The issue is which redox couple it participates in.

distractors.answer: The problem is that Fe(s) will dissolve too quickly to measure a stable voltage
distractors.explanation: Rate of dissolution is not the issue. The problem is the wrong redox couple being used.

toLevel5.question: In a mixture of MnO₄⁻ (E° = +1.51 V for MnO₄⁻/Mn²⁺ in acid), Cr₂O₇²⁻ (E° = +1.33 V), and Fe³⁺ (E° = +0.77 V) with a Zn electrode, a student says MnO₄⁻ is reduced but uses E° = +0.77 V for the cathode calculation. What is wrong?
toLevel5.correct: The student used the wrong E° value — MnO₄⁻/Mn²⁺ has E° = +1.51 V, not +0.77 V
toLevel5.correctExplanation: While correctly identifying MnO₄⁻ as the cathode reaction, the student substituted the E° for Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺ (+0.77 V) instead of MnO₄⁻/Mn²⁺ (+1.51 V).

distractors.answer: The student should have used Cr₂O₇²⁻ at the cathode because it has a moderate E° value
distractors.explanation: MnO₄⁻ has the highest E° (+1.51 V) and is correctly identified as the cathode reaction.

distractors.answer: The student should have added all three E° values together for the cathode potential
distractors.explanation: Only one cathode reaction occurs. The cathode E° is the single value of the reacting species.

distractors.answer: The student's error is using Zn at the anode instead of a stronger reducing agent
distractors.explanation: Zn is the only reducing agent present, so using it at the anode is correct. The E° value assignment is the error.

toLevel5.question: A cell operates with Br₂/Br⁻ at the cathode and Zn/Zn²⁺ at the anode. If I⁻ is added to the cathode half-cell, does the cell change?
toLevel5.correct: No — I⁻ is a reducing agent but weaker than Zn (I₂/I⁻ at +0.54 V vs Zn²⁺/Zn at −0.76 V), so it remains a spectator
toLevel5.correctExplanation: I⁻ is on the right side of the ECS. Its couple (I₂/I⁻) is at +0.54 V, much higher than Zn at −0.76 V. Zn remains the stronger reducing agent.

distractors.answer: Yes — I⁻ will be oxidised to I₂ at the cathode, competing with Br₂ reduction
distractors.explanation: I⁻ could potentially react with Br₂ directly, but in the galvanic cell context, the electrode reactions are determined by the ECS. Zn remains the anode.

distractors.answer: Yes — I⁻ will be reduced to I²⁻ ions, changing the cathode reaction
distractors.explanation: I⁻ is already reduced. It cannot gain more electrons. It acts as a spectator.

distractors.answer: Yes — adding I⁻ will neutralise the Br₂ and stop the cathode reaction
distractors.explanation: In a galvanic cell, the half-cells are separate. I⁻ in the cathode compartment does not consume Br₂ directly.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the analysis of a complex galvanic cell system.
toLevel5.sentence: In a cell with Ag⁺, Cu²⁺, Fe³⁺, Pb²⁺ ions and Zn/Al electrodes, the maximum E°cell = {{blank:1}} − ({{blank:2}}) = +2.46 V, using the strongest oxidising and reducing agents.

1.correctExplanation: Ag⁺/Ag has E° = +0.80 V, the highest of all oxidising agents present, making it the cathode reaction.

distractors.explanation: +0.77 V is Fe³⁺/Fe²⁺. While close, Ag⁺ (+0.80 V) is higher and is reduced.
+0.34 V is Cu²⁺/Cu, a weaker oxidising agent than Ag⁺.

2.correctExplanation: Al³⁺/Al has E° = −1.66 V, lower than Zn²⁺/Zn (−0.76 V), so Al is the strongest reducing agent and the anode.

distractors.explanation: −0.76 V is Zn²⁺/Zn. While Zn is present, Al (−1.66 V) is the stronger reducing agent.
−0.13 V is Pb²⁺/Pb, an oxidising agent in solution, not the anode metal.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the analysis of sequential reactions in a galvanic cell.
toLevel5.sentence: After the strongest oxidising agent ({{blank:1}}) is consumed, the next strongest oxidising agent ({{blank:2}}) will be reduced, and the cell voltage will decrease.

1.correctExplanation: Ag⁺ has the highest E° (+0.80 V) of common metal cations, so it is reduced first.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) is weaker than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V) and would be reduced second.

distractors.answer: Fe³⁺
distractors.explanation: Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) is slightly weaker than Ag⁺ (+0.80 V) and would be reduced second.

2.correctExplanation: Fe³⁺ has E° = +0.77 V, the next highest after Ag⁺ (+0.80 V), so it is reduced next.

distractors.answer: Cu²⁺
distractors.explanation: Cu²⁺ (+0.34 V) is weaker than Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V). Fe³⁺ is reduced before Cu²⁺.

distractors.answer: Pb²⁺
distractors.explanation: Pb²⁺ (−0.13 V) is much weaker. Fe³⁺ (+0.77 V) is the next in line after Ag⁺.
